string_table.string: Skip navigation. Press enter to return to the slide.
To watch this video, use the preview feature in Storyline 360, upload your published output to a server, publish to Review 360, or switch to static video quality.
Streaming video is unavailable for local playback.
Use the w, a, s, and d keys to move around the 360 degree image. Press the tab key to jump to interactive markers and hotspots.
You must complete the question before submitting.
Enter your name in the field below:
You have reached the time limit set for the quiz. Press 'OK' to continue.

slidelink.displaytext: When breaking news happens, where do you go to find information?
Where do you prefer to get your news?
Aspects to consider when reviewing a source

resource_data.description: Here are some useful links:

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript: <Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Welcome to Temple University Libraries Analytical Reading & Writing online module!" /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Where do you prefer to get your news?" /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="When you’re asked to use outside sources in a paper, it can be difficult to figure out where to find sources and whether they are appropriate for academic research.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="To begin, it may be helpful to think about the variety of source types you might use, and which you’re likely to find based on the nature of your topic.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Let’s walk through the Information Timeline. Click each tab to the right to learn more." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Now let’s take a closer look at several source types and consider each aspect. Click each type to learn more." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="While knowing the characteristics of sources types is helpful, it is also important to consider how you use your sources. Any type of source might be appropriate for a research project, depending on how you use it. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Let’s take a look at the BEAM method, developed by Joseph Bizup.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Click each to learn more." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="You should now have an understanding of the information timeline, source types and their uses, the library website and databases, and the research process." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Contact a librarian for additional help!" /> </Block> </Content> </Document>
<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Thank you!" /> </Block> </Content> </Document>
